title: installations fail if spack's install path is too long

labels.name: triage
labels.description: The issue needs to be prioritized

body:
<!-- Explain, in a clear and concise way, the command you ran and the result you were trying to achieve.
Example: "I ran `spack find` to list all the installed packages and ..." -->

Spack origin/develop now fails to install packages if the spack directory itself is cloned in a modestly deep path.  This is particularly problematic for CI environments where the CI framework is dictating the path/sandbox to use for testing.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

You can reproduce the problem with this script, which creates a 103 character directory, clones, spack, and attempts to install a package:

```
#!/bin/bash

LONGPATH="/tmp/path_that_is_kinda_long_but_not_that_looooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooong"

echo =======================================================
echo === Testing spack install in path with length `echo $LONGPATH | wc -c`:
echo =======================================================
mkdir -p $LONGPATH
cd $LONGPATH
git clone https://github.com/spack/spack.git
. spack/share/spack/setup-env.sh
spack install ed
if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
    echo "=== FAILURE"
else
    echo "=== SUCCESS"
fi

rm -rf $LONGPATH
```

### Error Message

`==> Error: SbangPathError: Install tree root is too long. Spack cannot patch shebang lines.`

### Information on your system

I have triggered this on 4 different systems.  I don't think it matters much, but the above script was tested on Ubuntu 20.10.
